conclusion: Two objects, A and B, move along the same line from the same starting position; their velocities over time are plotted on a graph.
Graph shows velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis with two curves for A and B.
Velocity of A increases steadily over time; velocity of B decreases, reaches a minimum, then increases.
Vertical dashed lines at times t1 and t2, and a red dot on the graph.
Positions at any time t can be found by integrating velocity functions from time 0 to t.
Distance between objects is the integral of their velocity difference from time 0 to t.
To find when they are farthest apart, find the time t where this distance is maximized.
Velocities of A and B are denoted as v_A(t) and v_B(t).
Distance is |âˆ« from 0 to t (v_A(t) - v_B(t)) dt|.
Maximize the integral over time t to find maximum distance.
A is always moving in the positive direction; B's velocity dips but doesn't go negative.
Distance increases as long as velocities are different; decreases when velocities are equal.
Point where velocities are equal is significant for maximum distance.
At time t2, red dot indicates curves intersect and velocities are equal.
At t2, distance might be maximized as velocities are equal and B may start catching up.
From t=0 to t2, A moves faster than B, increasing distance.
At t2, separation rate is the same, so distance isn't changing.
After t2, if B's velocity increases faster, B catches up, decreasing distance.
Maximum distance is at time t2.
After t2, B's velocity increases more rapidly, so B gains on A.
At time t2, they are farthest apart; after that, B closes the gap.
Answer is at time t2.
Consider area under the velocity-time graph for positions.
